title: 4 Ways to Insert a Background Image on One Page in Word

steps.title: Click the View tab.
steps.content: Click the View tab. It’ll be easier to work with an image on a single page if you isolate that page in your document window. To get started, go to the View tab in the ribbon menu at the top of the window. This method will work on both Windows and Mac.

steps.title: Select One Page.
steps.content: Select One Page . Scroll to the page where you’d like to put the background image, then go up to the Zoom group in the View tab. Select One Page to fit the whole page to your document window.

steps.title: Open the Insert tab.
steps.content: Open the Insert tab. Navigate to the Insert tab in the ribbon menu at the top of the page. Click on the tab to open it. [1] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Shapes.
steps.content: Click Shapes . This will open a menu displaying all the possible shapes that you can insert into your document. [2] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Select a rectangle.
steps.content: Select a rectangle. You can also select different shapes, but a rectangle is the best choice if you want to fill the entire background of the page with the image. Click the shape, then click on the page to insert it into the document. [3] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Drag the edges of the rectangle to fit the page.
steps.content: Drag the edges of the rectangle to fit the page. Click in the middle of the rectangle to drag it into the middle of the page, then click on one of the “handles” on an edge or corner of the shape. Hold down your mouse button and drag to expand the rectangle until it meets an edge of the page. Do this on all sides of the rectangle until it fills the page completely. [4] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source If you’d rather not fill the page all the way, simply drag the rectangle into whatever size and position you like. You can also set the shape to a specific size by clicking the Shape Format tab while the shape is selected, then entering the desired measurements in the Height and Width boxes.

steps.title: Navigate to the Shape Format tab.
steps.content: Navigate to the Shape Format tab. Keep the shape selected and open the Shape Format tab. [5] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source If you’re using the Windows version of Word, you can also go to the Drawing Tools tab. [6] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Select Shape Fill.
steps.content: Select Shape Fill . In the Shape Format tab or the Drawing Tools tab, look for a button labeled Shape Fill . Click the down arrow next to the button to open a menu with different fill options. [7] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Picture….
steps.content: Click Picture… . In the drop-down menu, select Picture… from the list of options. This will allow you to fill the shape with the image of your choice. [8] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Choose an image from your computer.
steps.content: Choose an image from your computer. Once you click Picture…, a dialog box will open prompting you to insert an image. Browse your computer to find the image you want to use, select it, then click Insert . [9] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source Once you do this, the image will appear inside the shape. However, it will appear stretched and distorted if the shape doesn’t match the dimensions of the original picture.

steps.title: Select Tile picture as texture.
steps.content: Select Tile picture as texture . With the shape still selected, either right-click the shape and select Format Shape… or navigate to the Format Pane in the Shape Format tab. Select the Fill button in the Format Pane and check the box next to Tile picture as texture . [10] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source The Tile picture as texture option will fill the shape with repeated copies of your image. This is a good option if you want to use an abstract or repeating pattern as your background image.

steps.title: Increase transparency to make the image fainter.
steps.content: Increase transparency to make the image fainter. If the picture is too dark or vibrant, it may be hard to see your text against it. While you’re still in the Format Pane , select the Image tab, then click Picture Transparency . Move the slider to make the image as transparent as you like. [11] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Set the outline to No Outline.
steps.content: Set the outline to No Outline . In the Shape Format tab, look for an Outline button next to the Shape Fill button. Click it to open the drop-down menu, then click No Outline . If you’re using the Windows version of Word, you can also right-click the shape to open a format menu. Select Outline , then No Outline . [12] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Right-click the shape and select Wrap Text.
steps.content: Right-click the shape and select Wrap Text . Now that the shape is in place, you’ll need to put it behind the text if you want it to show up in the background. You can either bring up this option by right-clicking the image and selecting Wrap Text or by navigating to the Layout tab and finding Wrap Text in the Selection group. [13] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Select Behind Text from the text wrapping options.
steps.content: Select Behind Text from the text wrapping options. Once you do this, the shape will appear behind your text as a background image. [14] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Open the Design tab.
steps.content: Open the Design tab. Open your Word document, then navigate to the Design tab in the ribbon menu at the top of the window. Click on the tab to open it. [15] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Watermark.
steps.content: Click Watermark . This is in the Page Background section. [16] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Select Custom Watermark.
steps.content: Select Custom Watermark . This will allow you to create your own watermark from an image rather than choosing one of the preset watermarks in the Word gallery. [17] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Picture Watermark and select your image.
steps.content: Click Picture Watermark and select your image. Once you choose Picture Watermark , you’ll be prompted to select an image. Click From a file to browse your computer, Binge Image Search to find one on the web, or OneDrive to browse your OneDrive. [18] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source Once you find the image you want, click Insert to add the watermark.

steps.title: Select Apply, then Close.
steps.content: Select Apply , then Close . The watermark will be added to

steps.title: Open the header and select the watermark image.
steps.content: Open the header and select the watermark image. Double-click near the top of the page to open the header. Then, move your cursor over the watermark. Your cursor should change to a 4-headed selection arrow. Click the watermark to select it. [19] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Navigate to the Design tab.
steps.content: Navigate to the Design tab. With the watermark still selected, go to the Design tab in the ribbon menu at the top of the window. [20] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Watermark in the Page Background group.
steps.content: Click Watermark in the Page Background group. This will open options for editing your custom watermark. [21] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Save your watermark to the gallery.
steps.content: Save your watermark to the gallery. Select Save Selection to Watermark Gallery in the drop-down menu. Enter a name for your new watermark image. Then, click OK to save it. [22] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Delete the watermark.
steps.content: Delete the watermark. To apply the watermark to just one page, you’ll need to delete it first and then reapply it. You can do this by pressing the Delete key while the watermark is still selected, or by opening Watermark in the Design tab and selecting No watermark . [23] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Open the Watermark menu again.
steps.content: Open the Watermark menu again. Click the page where you want the watermark to appear, then click Watermark in the Design tab. This should open up a gallery of saved watermarks, including your custom design. [24] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Right-click the watermark you want in the gallery.
steps.content: Right-click the watermark you want in the gallery. Locate your custom watermark in the gallery and right-click on it to open a context menu. [25] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Select Insert at Current Document Position.
steps.content: Select Insert at Current Document Position . This should be the first option on the menu. When you select it, the watermark image will appear on just the page that you selected. [26] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Adjust the boldness of the watermark if you like.
steps.content: Adjust the boldness of the watermark if you like. The watermark will automatically appear as a faint, washed-out image behind the text. If you want it to look bolder, select the watermark again, then open the Picture Tools tab. Select Format , then select Recolor , Brightness , or Contrast to adjust its appearance. [27] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Navigate to the Layout tab.
steps.content: Navigate to the Layout tab. To add a watermark to just one page in the Mac version of Word, you’ll need to isolate that page from the rest of the document. Start by going to the Layout tab in the ribbon menu at the top of the document window. [28] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Insert section breaks before and after the page.
steps.content: Insert section breaks before and after the page. Scroll to the bottom of the page just before the one where you want the watermark to appear, then click the Breaks button in the Layout tab. Go to the Section Breaks section of the menu and select Next Page . Do the same thing at the bottom of the page where you want the watermark to appear. If you’re putting the watermark on the first page of the document, you only need to insert a break at the bottom of that page.

steps.title: Go to the Design tab.
steps.content: Go to the Design tab. Once you’ve inserted the section breaks, navigate to Design in the ribbon menu and click on it. [29] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Select Watermark.
steps.content: Select Watermark . The Watermark button is located on the far right side of the Design tab. Click it to open a dialog box with options for inserting a watermark. [30] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Turn on the Picture radio button.
steps.content: Turn on the Picture radio button. Once the dialog box pops up, click the button next to Picture . This is the second option, right under No watermark . [31] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Insert your image.
steps.content: Insert your image. Click the Select Picture… button and select the image you want to use for your watermark. Click Insert , and then click OK to apply the watermark. [32] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source By default, your watermark will appear washed out and will be automatically scaled to fit the page. It will also appear on every page in the document. Uncheck the Washout option if you want the watermark to appear with its original brightness and contrast. Change the scale with the Scale dropdown menu to make the image bigger or smaller.

steps.title: Double-click at the top of the page to open the Header & Footer tab.
steps.content: Double-click at the top of the page to open the Header & Footer tab . Navigate to the page where you want the watermark to appear, then double-click at the top. This will open the header and footer, and will automatically take you to the Header & Footer tab in the ribbon menu. You can also go to the Insert tab, then select Header . Then, scroll to the bottom of the dropdown menu and select Edit Header .

steps.title: Deselect Link to Previous.
steps.content: Deselect Link to Previous . Click the header at the top of the page, then navigate to Link to Previous in the Header & Footer tab. Make sure that this option is deselected. Do the same thing with the header on the next page after the one where you want the watermark to appear.

steps.title: Select the watermark on any pages where you don’t want it to appear.
steps.content: Select the watermark on any pages where you don’t want it to appear. With the Header & Footer tab still open, scroll to any pages where you don’t want to have the watermark visible. Hover your cursor over the watermark and click on it to select it.

steps.title: Press Delete to remove the watermark.
steps.content: Press Delete to remove the watermark. The watermark should disappear from that page and any pages that are linked to it. You should still see the watermark on the page that you isolated with the section breaks. [33] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Close the Header and Footer.
steps.content: Close the Header and Footer. Once you’ve deleted the watermark from any pages where you don’t want it to appear, click on Close Header and Footer on the right side of the Header & Footer menu. Now you will have a watermark image in the background of just one page.

steps.title: Open the Insert tab.
steps.content: Open the Insert tab. Navigate to the page where you want the image to appear, then click the Insert tab in the ribbon menu at the top of the document. [34] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source This method will work on both Windows and Mac.

steps.title: Click Pictures.
steps.content: Click Pictures . You can find this in the Illustrations section.

steps.title: Select an option.
steps.content: Select an option. You can choose to find and select an image from your computer, from the web, or from a gallery of stock images or backgrounds.

steps.title: Choose an image and click Insert.
steps.content: Choose an image and click Insert . Once you’ve found the image you want, select it and click the Insert button to add it to your document. [35] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Position the image wherever you like on the page.
steps.content: Position the image wherever you like on the page. Once you insert the image, click it to select it, then drag it to your preferred position on the page. You can also use the “handles” on the edges and corners of the image to resize it. [36] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source If you want to resize the image without changing its proportions, select the image and open the Picture Format tab. Make sure the Lock aspect ratio box is checked, then type in either the height or width you want in the image size text boxes. The other dimension will automatically adjust to match.

steps.title: Right-click the image and select Wrap Text.
steps.content: Right-click the image and select Wrap Text . Or, if you’re on a Mac, use control-click. When the context menu pops up, select the Wrap Text option. You can also access the Wrap Text menu by navigating to the Layout tab while the image is selected. You’ll find it in the Selection Group on the right side of the ribbon menu.

steps.title: Select Behind Text.
steps.content: Select Behind Text . The Behind Text option will send the image to the background of your document. Once you deselect the image, you can type over it. [37] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Set the picture transparency in the Picture Format tab.
steps.content: Set the picture transparency in the Picture Format tab. If the image is too bold for you to easily see the text in front of it, you can adjust its transparency. With the image selected, go to the Picture Format tab and click the Transparency button. Select from one of the preset options or click Picture Transparency Options… to customize the transparency of the image. [38] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source
